Question_1.Context: The paper discusses the fabrication of a 3D hierarchically structured polyaniline nanoweb (3D HPN) for capturing drug-resistant bacteria from the skin surface.
Question_1.Question: What is the main purpose of constructing the 3D HPN?
Question_1.A: To detect viruses in the skin
Question_1.B: To capture and identify drug-resistant bacteria on the skin
Question_1.D: To study the effects of antibiotics on bacteria
Question_1.Source: we constructed a three-dimensional hierarchically structured polyaniline nanoweb (3D HPN) to capture, enrich, and detect drug-resistant bacteria on-site by rubbing infected skins.

Question_2.Context: The paper mentions the use of a real-time PCR-based molecular analysis to confirm single bacterial cell capturability and mechanical reliability against shear stress.
Question_2.Question: What method was used to confirm single bacterial cell capturability?
Question_2.Source: The real-time PCR results show the effective capturability of 3D HPN over a broad range of cell concentrations.

Question_3.Context: The paper discusses the entrapment and anti-release efficiency of 3D HPN when entrapping KPC-CRE bacteria.
Question_3.Question: What was the entrapment efficiency of 3D HPN with KPC-CRE concentrations ranging from 100 to 104 CFU/mL?
Question_3.Source: 3D HPN exhibits approximately 85% entrapment efficiency, which is determined in terms of Scheme 1.

Question_4.Context: The paper mentions the live/dead assay performed to confirm the state of the bacteria entrapped on 3D HPN.
Question_4.Question: What was observed in the live/dead assay after 1-hour entrapment of KPC-CRE?
Question_4.Source: Figure 2c shows several dead bacteria on 3D HPN after 1 h entrapment.

Question_5.Context: The paper discusses the practical applicability of 3D HPN for pathogenic bacterial entrapment and detection.
Question_5.Question: What was used as a realistic model of human skin in the study?
Question_5.Source: Micropig skin was selected as a realistic model of human skin.

Question_6.Context: The paper mentions the fabrication of 3D HPN films for capturing MDR KPC-CRE from the skin surface.
Question_6.Question: What was the detection sensitivity of the real-time PCR assay using 3D HPN?
Question_6.Source: The detection sensitivity of this assay is 102 CFU/mL.

Question_7.Context: The paper discusses the entrapment and analysis of bacteria on 3D HPN.
Question_7.Question: What was the entrapment coverage when 107 cells were loaded on 3D HPN?
Question_7.Source: Entrapment coverage displays a maximum of 75 counts per 100 μm2 when 107 cells are loaded.

Question_8.Context: The paper mentions the anti-release efficiency evaluation of 3D HPN when entrapping KPC-CRE bacteria.
Question_8.Question: What was the anti-release efficiency of 3D HPN with KPC-CRE concentrations ranging from 100 to 104 CFU/mL?
Question_8.Source: 3D HPN exhibits 100% anti-release efficiency for the given KPC-CRE concentrations.

Question_9.Context: The paper discusses the synthesis of 3D HPN and its characterization.
Question_9.Question: What were the layers deposited on the surface of PUN films during the fabrication of 3D HPN?
Question_9.Source: In addition, 20 nm thick titanium (Ti) and 200 nm thick gold (Au) were deposited on the surface of PUN films.

Question_10.Context: The paper mentions the use of a real-time PCR-based molecular analysis to confirm single bacterial cell capturability and mechanical reliability against shear stress.
Question_10.Question: What was the sensitivity of the real-time PCR assay using 3D HPN?
Question_10.Source: The detection sensitivity of this assay is 102 CFU/mL.
